msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: In primam partem Samuelis libri iv

rubric.note: not filled in, note to rubricator trimmed

msItem.incipit: fol. 1ra Helcana uir unus in rama
msItem.explicit: fol. 2va et ieiuniis a domino malorum leuamenta deposcunt.

msItem.incipit: fol. 3ra Studium nobis frequentiamque legendi ac meditandi litteras sanctas commendans apostolis⸵ ait.
msItem.explicit: fol. 18rb At in singulis his quibus dei filius a deo patre declaratur ipse se filius hominibus hominem
msItem.note: Remainder of the column and fol. 3v left blank.

msItem.incipit: fol. 19ra intuenda coniungite taliterque ęcclesiam ornatam idest et fidei misteriis˷
msItem.explicit: fol. 145vb utrique pariter iuuante cristi gratia perpetua festiuitate gaudebunt.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber .iiii. Bede presbiteri expositionis Allegorice Super Samuelem.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: In Regum librum xxx quaestiones
msItem.rubric: fol. 135vb Incipit liber eiusdem. De .xxxᵗª. questionibus Super Regum Ad Litteram.

msItem.incipit: Dilectissimo fratri nothelmo beda salutem. Quę de libro regum dilucidanda tibi frater dilectissime misisti. statim prout domino iuuante potui explicare curaui⸵
msItem.explicit: fol. 146rb nobis quoque otius hoc destinare non graueris. Bene uale semper dilectissime in cristo frater.

msItem.incipit: Et suscitabo mihi sacerdotem fidelem etc.
msItem.explicit: fol. 146va Et transtulit ierusalem omnem et uniuersos principes etc.

msItem.incipit: Quod ait propheta ad heli loquens ex persona dei et suscitabo mihi sacerdotem fidelem˷ qui iuxta cor meum et animam meam faciat˷ et ędificabo
msItem.explicit: fol. 159rb Intrate in gaudium domini uestri.

supportDesc.extent: 159 leaves (with upper and lower parchment pastedowns)
supportDesc.collation: a2, 1–198, 208-3 (6–8 canc.) The first two leaves, containing the list of capitula, are a contemporary addition, written in a different hand from the first gathering and using a modified ruling pattern. Most gatherings numbered in ink at the centre of the foot of the last page. Denique inuasus (with capitula) [bea]ti samuelis lectio

layoutDesc.layout: Fols. 1r–2v, table of contents, ruled in drypoint, with pricking on outer edges of page for frame and individual lines. On fol. 2r, horizontal rules occur, from top to bottom, at 34 | 42 | 249 | 263 | 329 mm; vertical rules, from left to right, at 16 | 82 | 89.5 | 96.5 | 162 | 213 mm. Line spacing 6.5 mm.

Fols. 3r–159v ruled in drypoint, with pricking on outer edges of page for frame and individual lines. On fol. 112r, horizontal rules occur, from top to bottom, at 34 | 48 | 249.5 | 264 | 330 mm; vertical rules, from left to right, at 16 | 83 | 90 | 97 | 164 | 217 mm. Line spacing 6.5 mm.

handDesc.handNote: Protogothic, s. xii3/4. The hand of Fulcon is known from several other manuscripts; see Watson, no. 799. Some passages and corrections appear to be in the hand of Walter de Melida.

decoDesc.decoNote: New books open with large, intricately decorated initials. Fol. 3ra, prologue, 4-line red S; fol. 3vb, book 1, 7-line green and blue F with red, blue, green, and golden decoration; fol. 27vb, book 2, 8-line red Q with green and golden decoration. New chapters generally begin with enlarged capitals, alternating between red and green. In list of capitula on folw. 1r–2v, some experimentation with using silver leaf as an underlay to red initials.

additions.p: On front cover, table of contents in hand of John Prise and Beda (s. xvi?).
Pressmarks: 8 (spine); 1 Arch. 2-19 (label on spine, upper flyleaf); MS. Jesus Coll. Ox. C. 53 (blue label on spine).

binding.p: Romanesque, whittawed leather over oak boards, bevelled edge. Partially recovered. Blue and white endbands. Staple holes for chain on lower board.

history.origin: Written at Cirencester Abbey between 1149 or 1168 and 1176. On fol. 159v, in a slightly later hand, Liber sancte Marie De Cirecestr’. D’ Andree Abbatis secundi tempore scriptus per manum D’ Fulconis canonici postea prioris D’ Alexandro de Weleu tunc cantore. Andrew was abbot from 1147 to 1176. Alexander of Wellow was preceded in office by Adam de Lamora, who was not cantor before 1149. Watson notes that if this Alexander can be identified with a canon who witnesses an Oseney Abbey charter datable between 1157 and 1168, Adam was likely still cantor at this time: H.E. Salter, ed., Cartulary of Oseney Abbey, Oxford Historical Society 98 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1935), 5:26–27 (no. 538A). (The dating is based on a reference to the memory of John de Pageham, bishop of Worcester from 1151 to 1157, and the document was issued during the abbacy of Wigod, 1154 to 1168.)
history.acquisition: Appears in the list of the books of John Prise in the 1602 donation willed to Jesus College by his son Gregory Prise (1535–1600). Neil R. Ker, ‘Sir John Prise’, The Library, 5th ser., 10, no. 1 (March 1955): 1–24.

listBibl.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts c. 435–1600 in Oxford Libraries (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1984), no. 799 and pl. 56.
